title: 'I can't be silent': Ida man starts Pro Life Man
description:
'I can't be silent'
Ida man starts Pro Life Man
text_headers: 'I can't be silent': Ida man starts Pro Life Man
text: 'I can't be silent': Ida man starts Pro Life ManNews Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  NEWS'I can't be silent': Ida man starts Pro Life ManSuzanne Nolan WislerThe Monroe NewsIda’s Andy Griffith is a pro-life man.Several years ago, Griffith, a licensed EMT and EMS coordinator, was looking to join a pro-life group specifically for men.After hours of searching online, he found none. But, he did learn the domain www.prolifeman.org was available to purchase.Griffith bought it, without knowing what was next.In the fall of 2018, he launched Pro Life Man, a national, virtual organization based in Monroe County. In January, Pro Life Man expanded, adding Fort Hope, a support program for men suffering from the effects of abortion.“I was personally convicted that I needed to do more in the pro-life movement. I needed to save babies from abortion,” Griffith, a member of Redeemer Fellowship Church of Monroe, said.Pro Life Man’s motto is “No Longer Silent.”“We need to change the idea that since men don’t have a uterus they can’t have an opinion on abortion. In my view, abortion kills a human child. If that’s my view, I can’t be silent. I want to encourage other men to be no longer silent too,” Griffith said. “Our No. 1 mission is to be the voice for pre-born sons and daughters. We say ‘sons and daughters’ to rehumanize the child in the womb. Our No. 2 mission is the provide help and healing to men.”His organization targets men directly.“Usually, pro-life (efforts) are very feminine and adjust slightly so men might like it. They don’t really do a good job. (Our) branding and marketing is very masculine. It has a military feel. A lot of men resonate with that. Our most popular shirt says ‘Pro-Life Warrior.’ Fort Hope also has a military theme,” Griffith said.Pro Life Man doesn’t have in-person events. Instead, it uses social media platforms like its website, Facebook, Instagram and YouTube, and radio, national podcasts and blog postings to spread its pro-life messages.“We’ve gone to local events, rallies and marches. In August, 2020, we had a wild game dinner fundraiser. But, we don’t plan to go in-person. We have an online presence,” Griffith said. “We post memes. We just had a week of Harry Potter-themed memes. We engage in popular culture and add a pro-life message. We have blog posts and arguments. We post rebuttals to popular pro-choice and pro-abortion (messages). Our entire board is licensed medical professionals. We didn’t plan it that way. We give a lot of arguments from the medical side.”Pro Life Man has found a national audience of roughly 20,000 so far. The top three states for visitors are Michigan, Texas and California.Quickly, Griffith learned from the audience that men also needed support and healing.“This was not my plan at all, but there was this need. Men started reaching out, saying, ‘I’m hurting because of this abortion.’ They had no say or they had a part in it and now regret it,” Griffith said. “Men are also impacted by abortion. Men can grieve that lost child.”Still, he was initially hesitant.“I felt in a time of prayer God was imparting on me to start this. I said, ‘I’m not the man for this job.’ I don’t even consider myself skilled or gifted in (support),” he said.In January, Pro Life Man launched Fort Hope, which Griffith calls a “healing program by men, for men.” Inquiring men can receive support and someone to talk to on the phone or on Zoom.So far, six have sought support.“Our vice president, Thomas White, director of Fort Hope, who also is an EMT, has this tremendous compassion and empathetic heart. He does so well with supporting others,” Griffith said. “We have a plan, step-by-step and walk them through. The end goal is healing."The healing plan also includes connecting the men with a pastor.“We get them connected with a local pastor in their area. Our contact with them is limited. By giving them connection to a local pastor, the support can be more long-term. (The men we’ve worked with so far) expressed that it helped them,” Griffith said.Griffith believes the need for support for men affected by abortion is great.“No one really knows the statistics. Men are more reserved, they keep everything inside and do not want to talk about it. It’s hard to study. Statistics say one in four women have had an abortion. We have to think (those numbers) are similar for men,” Griffith said.Pro Life Man's website says 64,004,478 abortions have taken place in the U.S. since Roe v. Wade.Griffith cited a study of 1,000 men who were involved in abortions. 2/3 said they felt guilt and 1/3 suffered regret.Recently, Fort Hope began a partnership with Monroe’s Selah’s Center of Hope. The center will now refer men grieving aborted children to Fort Hope. Griffith said the next step is partnering with Care Net.“It’s a national organization of 11,000 affiliated crisis pregnancy centers across the country. We want to partner with them and get Fort Hope in all the center. We can reach out to all the center (and tell them) if men need this kind of advice, they can refer them to us,” Griffith said.Pro Life Man has a five-member board of volunteers. Only two of its staff members are paid. Griffith is the organization’s president and doesn’t take a salary. Other directors are White, vice president and Fort Hope director; Denise Hunter, secretary; Linda Andreoli, treasurer; Josh Lewis, board member, and Liam Slavin, communications specialist.Pro Life Man also has an advisory board of 26 people from all across Monroe County.“We reach out to them for advice and suggestions,” Griffith said. “Lots of pastors are on the board.”For more information, visit www.prolifeman.org, Pro Life Man on Facebook, or pro_life_man on Instagram.Careers Accessibility Site Map Legals Our Ethical Principles Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Terms of Service Privacy Policy Your Privacy Choices Staff DirectoryContact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Advertising Terms and Conditions Buy and Sell Help Center Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give FeedbackSubscribe Today Newsletters Facebook X eNewspaper ArchivesJobs Cars Homes Classifieds Reviewed.com 10Best LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions© 2024 www.monroenews.com.
